published_attributes.title: üí° Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
‚ùóAll branding related topics can be found within Branding area space Just like with any other design project designing branding cannot be properly accomplished in a vacuum and should be based on thoroughly researched data and information. The client‚Äôs involvement is vital throughout the entirety of the process, but will be required to the highest degree during the initial, discovery phases.

While the outcome of many design-related projects can rely on the designer‚Äôs knowledge, skills and experience, branding is by far the most client driven as it‚Äôs almost entirely dependent¬†on how the client wants for their brand to be perceived.

Therefore the preparation and discovery phases for any branding project should be diligent and conscious, not only on the part of the designer, but the client‚Äôs as well. It is vital to provide the client with ample opportunity to establish their needs and expectations as well as let them come to any conclusions on their own.

It‚Äôs important to help your clients in this ‚Äújourney‚Äù and have ways to guide them, but it‚Äôs best to avoid directing them too much.

published_attributes.title: üìÑ The brief
published_attributes.serialized_body: A well crafted brief is something we should strive to have before we begin any other work. If the client did not provide us with one, it‚Äôs a good practice to prepare a questionnaire with several of the key questions (i.e. about the company‚Äôs profile, their market position, target audience, products, marketing strategies, etc.) that will serve as a basis for a brief. The more information we can get at this stage, the easier it will be to prepare the next stages of the projects, especially any potential workshops.¬†

The more information we can get at this stage, the easier it will be to prepare the next stages of the projects, especially any potential workshops.¬†

published_attributes.title: üîé Market and user research
published_attributes.serialized_body:
To get a good idea what kind of project we‚Äôll be tackling, we need to take a closer look at the client‚Äôs position on the market, their competitors and their target audience. This has a twofold purpose. The first is to find the right tone and identity for the brand, so that it fits its market space and is properly directed to their end user. The second purpose is to differentiate your client‚Äôs brand from those of their competition. While you want the visual identity and messaging to fit the industry and target demographic, you also want it to be unique and distinct. Ideally, you‚Äôll also want it to be better than the competition ;) Now research for branding isn‚Äôt that much different than what you‚Äôd do for a website or a mobile app. But the resulting report will be somewhat broader, as you should not only take note of the visual aspect, but the marketing and market impact as well. It‚Äôs worth understanding not only who we‚Äôll be going against, but also how high the bar is set. The problem with providing any benchmarks that might provide an additional insight, is that branding quality is hard to quantify in any meaningful way, as it‚Äôs difficult, if not impossible, to measure in any objective manner. Ultimately, the goal of the research is to determine who will need to be ‚Äúimpressed‚Äù by the end result of the task at hand.

An excellent example of a properly conducted and concluded market research can be found in AltoStack‚Äôs research report that can be viewed here:¬†

  • Altostack research - G.Drive

published_attributes.title: üéØ Business Goals
published_attributes.serialized_body:
It‚Äôs important to remember that it‚Äôs the client‚Äôs responsibility to determine what their business goals are. Our job is to produce a visual identity aligned with those goals, but it‚Äôs neither in our competence, nor the project‚Äôs best interest to get too involved in this stage. Most companies will have those goals clearly defined as it‚Äôs very often a part of their business plan, but some startups and companies that are aiming to redefine their position on the market might need to deliberate on a matter a while longer.

It‚Äôs best not do pressure your client at this stage, as a wrongly defined direction will impact the whole project. Now those goals might be in a bit of a flux during the process as the client's priorities evolve, so it‚Äôs good to approach this with a degree of flexibility. That being said, we would suggest establishing the brand‚Äôs overall direction before any workshops take place, as trying to define it during said workshops will eat into a significant portion of the time devoted to them.

published_attributes.title: üí° The workshops
published_attributes.serialized_body:
This really is the first proper stage of the creative process and should be strongly encouraged. While it‚Äôs possible to design a successful branding without conducting workshops, it‚Äôs also a lot more difficult and will most likely take significantly more time.

Workshops are an excellent opportunity to help your client to lock down the direction whey want to take with their brand, its structure, its messaging and the initial strategy, not necessarily on a visual level, but certainly on a conceptual one.

It‚Äôs also the time when aspects of the brand will be defined.

Broadly speaking those include:

  • A brand purpose Why does the brand exist? Why does it matter? What is the motivation behind the venture and how does the client act on that motivation?
  • Brand position What makes the brand unique? What makes it better than their competition? Who is their target audience?
  • Brand promise What does the brand communicate? What will it provide to their clients? What message does it send out?
  • Brand personality and brand values Who are they? If they were a person, what kind of person would they be? What traits do they possess? What tone of voice do they use?
  • Brand expression This is the main thing for us. How will the brand present itself from a visual standpoint? What will the logo be like? What colours and font types the brand will use? What will the visual direction for their videos, advertising and internal communication be. How do they wish to tell their stories.

There are various useful exercises created for workshops that will help with establishing the brand‚Äôs direction, but the topic is too broad to go into details here. You can find out more by checking the recordings about how to run workshops and exercises.

In the end the workshop‚Äôs conclusion should provide us with a strong sense of direction for the project and a brand ‚Äúessence‚Äù on which we can base the visual exploration for the project‚Äôs next phases.

In the end the workshop‚Äôs conclusion should provide us with a strong sense of direction for the project and a brand ‚Äúessence‚Äù on which we can base the visual exploration for the project‚Äôs next phases.

published_attributes.title: ‚ú® Inspirations and moodboards
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Think about the first design directions

During the previous steps you focused on getting to know a brand, conducted a research and set with the client a main brand values. It gave you a great base for designing or redesigning a new branding for the product. Based on all of the gathered information you should think about 2-3 design styles which you would like to propose. Those styles don‚Äôt always need to be completely dissimilar to each other, but the client needs to see a clear difference to understand how we distinguish those 3 similar styles. It is important to highlight the main visual elements and emphasise¬†core features which distinguish particular directions. Moodboards are a great way to experiment and present each direction. Sometimes it could give a surprising result and the client will love it. If this does not happen, be sure that the client is convinced about one of the other directions.

published_attributes.title: ‚ú® Inspirations and moodboards
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Prepare the moodboards for the client

Creating a moodboard is one of the easiest ways to start a discussion¬†about the overall visual direction with the client or with people related to the project. We use Moodboards to collect all inspirations in one place. It helps in building a visual reference, concepts and ideas - we can build a holistic overview of a project, and we can focus on specific elements eg. Photos, Color Palette, UI Elements, Typography etc. While creating Moodboards you should have your design direction which you would like to present to the client in mind. Focus on providing multiple directions that are still consistent with the brief and conversations with the client, not just having multiple examples of a single direction.

It will let you easily explain the differences between those direction and point out pros and cons for each of them. Moodboard presentation is important to see which direction is desired by the client and what are their expectations. You can also receive more insight about the brand and some business goals which weren‚Äôt mentioned before.

Sometimes the client is not convinced which design direction they would like to follow. You should ask:

  • What is s/he like in those moodboards which you prepared?
  • Are those design directions suited to their brand goals and their audience?
  • Were colors taken into consideration while choosing a moodboard?

You can read more about creating moodboards here:¬†

  • Working with moodboards

What is s/he like in those moodboards which you prepared?
Are those design directions suited to their brand goals and their audience?
Were colors taken into consideration while choosing a moodboard?
You can read more about creating moodboards here:¬†
Working with moodboards

It will let you easily explain the differences between those direction and point out pros and cons for each of them. Moodboard presentation is important to see which direction is desired by the client and what are their expectations. You can also receive more insight about the brand and some business goals which weren‚Äôt mentioned before.
Sometimes the client is not convinced which design direction they would like to follow. You should ask:
What is s/he like in those moodboards which you prepared?
Are those design directions suited to their brand goals and their audience?
Were colors taken into consideration while choosing a moodboard?
You can read more about creating moodboards here:¬†
Working with moodboards

published_attributes.title: üñä Logo design
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Once you have all information and materials from the client (after workshops, briefing, mood boards approval) you can now start designing the logo.¬†You can start from very basic sketches, thinking about design direction for the whole brand. Sometimes it‚Äôs good to show the first logo drafts to the client, especially when your idea is more complex (it will save a lot of time when you will be working on the final versions).¬†If you‚Äôre working on very basic sketches, you can show more than 3 ideas, but the final presentation should not contain more than 2 or 3 options. These 2-3 options should differ significantly from each other and represent different approaches.¬†On this stage it‚Äôs also good to test the logo on various backgrounds and set different sizes to see how the logo works in different conditions.

When you have all variants of the logo ready, it‚Äôs time to show it to the client. The best way to do it is to prepare a presentation (a pdf or InVision project where the client can add comments directly) which contains:

  • basic logo variants (on white and dark background),
  • The application of the logo, based on how it will be used the most - if the logo is for a digital product, show it in a digital context, If the usage will be broader show it also on collateral materials.

published_attributes.title: üí¨ Gathering feedback
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Presentation

It‚Äôs always good to use some realistic mockups, to make the presentation as real as possible on this stage. The more context you client sees in the presentations, the more chances that the logo will be accepted. You can find some of the mockups here:¬†

  • Branding mockups

You can find a link to example of presentation of logo for Zety :

  • Zety logo proposal

Once you send your presentation to the client they‚Äôll probably have some feedback for you. Sometimes it‚Äôs about changing or adjusting the colour, or maybe client would like to see some other typography options.¬†And then this magic moment comes and the client chooses one of your proposals.¬†When you have a green light, you have to prepare the final version of the logo (if your initial proposition was created as a draft). Maybe you will need to align some parts of the logo to the grid, set or adjust spacing, or the size. It‚Äôs really up to you.

Presentation

published_attributes.title: üñç Brand visual elements
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Typography

Brand is not only a logo, but it also contains a wide range of elements which create a whole "look and feel". One of these things is typography which is really important for all brands, especially for digital brands. In most cases they communicate with their audience through a website or their app. Tone of voice should be emphasised¬†by the font which you will choose. You should pick one typeface which will be a main for the company. If you want to choose more than one, you should think whether it‚Äôs really needed. You can differentiate a style by font size, weight and even color. It gives you lots of possibilities to experiment with the visual style. Using only one typeface will make sure that a product and all brand materials are coherent. You don‚Äôt know who will be using it, or if they will create new font pairings in the future and how they will approach it. But if you are convinced that two or even more typefaces are needed, choose the fonts which have a different style, eg. sans vs sans serif, wide vs narrow, ¬†thin vs extrabold, etc.

For product you need to think how much Text Styles would you like to use and how to use them. In the future it will be a good guideline for people working with a brand guidelines.

published_attributes.title: üñç Brand visual elements
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Colour palette (primary, secondary etc.)

Color is one of the elements which define the brand‚Äôs character. It can carry various connotations and has a huge impact on how the brand will be perceived. While you start to create the visual identity, you need to consider if you want to focus on one or pick multiple colors. A wisely picked color scheme will empower and highlight the visual style. We want to give the user an immediate understanding of what kind of brand s/he is facing.

You should also consider how the colors will be used across the brand. Sometimes colors which looks great in RGB, won‚Äôt look so nice when they‚Äôll be printed in the CMYK color space. If that happens, you can suggest a Pantone replacement, but bear in mind that it will increase the print cost and the client might not approve it. However, it's good practice to test the colours before you send them to the client.

Key visual

The key visual enhances brand recognition and creates the feeling you want your brand and product to be associated with. It helps users to know that those visuals are related to specific a brand even without using a logo. It needs to be unique, memorable, easily grasped and also evoke specific emotions. A great key visual will also allow build communication with the target user and emphasise¬†the individuality of the brand. ¬†

published_attributes.title: ‚úâÔ∏è Corporate brand style
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Depending on the client and product (business cards, letterhead, icons, etc.)

Depending on the client‚Äôs needs you will create a set of assets. Those could include:

  • Business cards
  • Correspondence (letterhead and envelopes)
  • Billboards, banners and posters
  • Vehicle branding
  • T-shirt and hats
  • Roll ups

Discuss with the client which materials are required. In most cases it will be only business cards and letterhead. Make sure that you‚Äôve prepared them as CMYK assets ready for print or you‚Äôve added a version which could be modified by client.

published_attributes.title: üìì Style guide
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Brand book is a kind of a document, where you have all branding materials gathered and well described. It‚Äôs the final step for a branding project. Of course the branding itself isn‚Äôt completed in any time, because it can still be updated (eg. with new brand elements).

Before you will start working on the brandbook, make sure that you have a full logo pack created. It‚Äôs very important to have all versions finalized and polished - especially when you will be working on logo construction drawings and all logo versions (full colour, monochromatic, achromatic etc.).

If you‚Äôre not familiar with the process of creating the brandbook, here‚Äôs the list of the most important pages:

1. Introduction (write sth about the purpose of the document)

2. Logo origins (show where your ideas come from)

3. Symbol/Logotype presentation (on white and dark background)

4. Variants of the logo (various configurations of the logo)

5. Logo on various backgrounds

6. Mono- and Achromatic versions of the logo (both on white and dark background)

7. Safe zone (show the white space around the logo)

8. Symbol and Logo construction (show some basic guidelines for the logo building, proportions, distances between elements)

9. Color palette (color usage across the logo and all elements of the branding)

10. Typography (if the logo was the only part of you work, don‚Äôt limit yourself to this - find a nice typeface that will be a perfect match for the logo and show some examples - headlines, paragraph)

11. Minimal sizes (set the minimal size for every logo variant, make sure that the logo is readable enough in these sizes; for digital versions check all on a monitor, for printable versions use simple printer and print a few variants - pick the best one)

4. Variants of the logo (various configurations of the logo)
5. Logo on various backgrounds
6. Mono- and Achromatic versions of the logo (both on white and dark background)
7. Safe zone (show the white space around the logo)
8. Symbol and Logo construction (show some basic guidelines for the logo building, proportions, distances between elements)
9. Color palette (color usage across the logo and all elements of the branding)

10. Typography (if the logo was the only part of you work, don‚Äôt limit yourself to this - find a nice typeface that will be a perfect match for the logo and show some examples - headlines, paragraph)

11. Minimal sizes (set the minimal size for every logo variant, make sure that the logo is readable enough in these sizes; for digital versions check all on a monitor, for printable versions use simple printer and print a few variants - pick the best one)

published_attributes.title: üèÅ Summary
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Ultimately, the goal should be to design a recognisable visual identify¬†with a unique language. While the core of the project flow isn't all that different from any other design project, there is a much greater emphasis on the discovery phase and the process itself requires a significantly bigger involvement from the client.¬†

Branding projects also usually¬†entail a bit more iterations than, say, a UI-focused project might - so that's something to bear in mind. The biggest takeaway however, is that due to the way the end product establishes itself on the market, there's really no easy way to iterate on it once it launches. Therefore it needs to be really well thought out and properly¬†developed before it's released.
